column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment

#Text=Covered entities under the U.S. Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act ( HIPAA ) of 1996 , are health plans , healthcare clearinghouses , and any healthcare provider who transmits health information in an electronic form .
#Text=Covered entities need to comply with the HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules in order to avoid penalties .
#Text=One of the Security Rule ’s main requirements is the performance of a risk analysis .
#Text=The Security Rule stipulates that a risk analysis should be documented but it does n’t require any specific format for it .
#Text=This article will present several steps of how to conduct a proper healthcare risk assessment .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Define the Scope of the Risk Analysis .
#Text=There are different types of risk analysis methods depending on its scope .

#Text=The scope of the healthcare risk assessment includes the potential risks and vulnerabilities to the confidentiality , availability and integrity of all ePHI that a covered entity creates , receives , maintains , or transmits .
#Text=Gather Current Documentation .
#Text=A covered entity should gather and document information on where ePHI is stored , maintained and transmitted .
#Text=This can be done by checking current and past projects , auditing documents .
#Text=Identify Potential Threats and Vulnerabilities .
#Text=This step is essential to determining the level of risk .
#Text=All anticipated threats ( natural , environmental or human ) and vulnerabilities should be documented in category lists and analyzed afterwards .
#Text=Analyze Current Security Measures .
#Text=All security measures that a covered entity uses to protect ePHI should be documented .
#Text=Security measures can be divided into technical – related to the software and hardware in the network - and non-technical – related to management and operations .
#Text=This step will reveal whether the covered entity has enough security safeguards in place .
#Text=Determine the Likelihood and Impact of Threats .
#Text=The covered entity has to analyze each threat and vulnerability combination in order to determine the probability a threat can occur .
#Text=The likelihood of threat occurrence can be defined as low , medium and high or can be a numeric representation .
#Text=The threat impact should also be defined by using a similar rating system .
#Text=Determine the Risk Level .
#Text=Make a risk level matrix using the identified likelihood and threat impact .
#Text=Choose a rating system such as the low , medium and high rating system .
#Text=Add an action description to each risk level , which will clarify to management what actions should be taken to prevent or minimize this risk and when .
#Text=Identify New Security Measures .
#Text=After identifying the risk level , covered entities have to think what security measures need to be taken to reduce risks .

#Text=When defining new security measures , it is important to take into account factors such as the measures ’ effectiveness , legislative or regulatory requirements and other organization ’s policies .
#Text=Like each of the previous steps , this step should also be diligently documented .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=EPHI can be found in various electronic media so covered entities should consider all forms of media containing ePHI in their analysis .
#Text=Examples of such media are hard drives , floppy disks , CDs , DVDs , smart cards , personal digital assistants ( PDA ) , transmission media , and portable electronic storage media .
#Text=Take into account all possible threat outcomes .

#Text=The most common impacts as a result of exploited vulnerabilities are loss or corruption of ePHI , disclosure or unavailability of ePHI , loss of software or hardware inventory , and loss of reputation .
